We report our findings on the infrared characteristics (3.6-24 microns) of young stellar objects in the nearby Serpens South star-forming region, utilizing data collected with the Infrared Array Camera (IRAC; Fazio et al., 2004) aboard the Spitzer Space Telescope.
We have identified 1,082 potential young stars based on their mid-infrared colors and luminosities, including 759 members previously recognized in this cluster.
Among the newly identified sources, we observe that only approximately half are linked to outflows as indicated by shocked H2 emission or radio continuum emission.
Most of the other new candidates seem to be deeply embedded protostars that have minimal circumstellar material.
These results indicate that numerous new candidates could embody a more primitive evolutionary phase compared to those previously identified in this cloud complex.

This aligns with earlier research indicating that a significant number of low-mass pre-main sequence stars in Serpens South have yet to be identified, largely due to their young ages and/or the relatively high levels of extinction in the region.
We examine the correlations between energy density and flux of a free scalar field in 1+1 dimensions, analyzing both finite temperature T and the vacuum state (T=0).
We demonstrate that these correlation functions remain nontrivial even when assessed on the light cone defined by the condition \(x+x=t+t_0=2ct\).
Specifically, we observe that they display power law behavior, with exponents that vary continuously with respect to c.
This contrasts with ordinary quantum mechanics, where such correlators identically vanish outside the light cone.
The results outlined here can be achieved by employing conventional techniques established within the scope of thermofield dynamics.
They offer additional proof that this formalism effectively describes thermal states even in non-equilibrium scenarios.
Energy density-flux correlations are crucial for a variety of physical phenomena, spanning from hydrodynamics to particle production in heavy ion collisions.
However, their calculations have been hindered by the necessity of obtaining information about the off-diagonal elements of the two-point function associated with the relevant operator.
In this section, we provide clear expressions for these quantities related to a free massless scalar field theory in one spatial dimension.

We share the findings from an analysis of high-resolution optical spectra collected using the Subaru Telescope, focusing on a sample of young, low-mass (0.5-2 Msun) pre-main-sequence stars in the Orion Nebula Cluster.
We observe that the majority of these objects exhibit notable periodic variability over timescales varying from 1 day to several months.
The observed periods align with what is anticipated if the photometric variations are caused by rotational modulation related to starspots and/or plages.
Furthermore, we observe pronounced Hα emission lines that suggest the presence of chromospheric activity.
Our observations indicate that a significant number of our targets exhibit relatively fast rotation rates when compared to older field dwarfs of similar masses.
This was probably the result of tidal locking that occurred during their formation.
In conclusion, we also present the discovery of two new spectroscopic binaries from our list of targets.
These systems could serve as important benchmarks for evaluating theoretical models of binary evolution.

We introduce the initial findings from a new family of templates, named SEOBNRv4HM, developed to identify gravitational waves (GWs) generated by binary black holes of similar mass, with total masses ranging from 10 to 100 solar masses.
We demonstrate that this family of templates can be utilized to search for gravitational wave signals from binary black holes using current ground-based detectors like Advanced LIGO/Virgo and KAGRA.
Additionally, we illustrate the usefulness of these templates for parameter estimation studies utilizing simulated data sets.
In conclusion, we will explore potential enhancements to our research.

Force is quantified in newtons (N) or dynes (dyne).

We investigated the distribution of molecular gas along the line of sight to the gravitationally lensed radio source B0218+357 by utilizing high-resolution millimeter-wave observations at 345 GHz and 1.3 mm with the Submillimeter Array (SMA) located at Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

We identified three compact continuum sources linked to each image component.
Through addition, we detected several faint emission lines, including CO (3-2), 13CO (3-2), HCN (4-3), CS (5-4), and SiO (8-7).
Based on these results, we infer that the total flux density consists of four components: one associated with each image and an extra component arising from the lensing galaxy.

By combining our SMA data with earlier single-dish measurements, we were able to derive physical parameters, including mass surface densities, column densities, temperatures, and volume densities for all four components.

The data indicates that this object will not collide with Earth in the next 100 years, but it could be a promising candidate for future space missions.

We investigate the decoherence dynamics of an open quantum system comprised of two-level atoms interacting with a single-mode cavity field, taking into account the effects of dissipation and external driving fields.

The coupling between the atom and the cavity is analyzed using the Jaynes-Cummings model, while the dissipative effects are characterized through the master equation for the system's reduced density matrix.
We demonstrate that an analytical solution for the steady state of this problem can be achieved when the decay rates of all atomic levels are uniform.

We specifically observe that the steady-state entanglement of the atom-field subsystem is influenced by both the intensity of the external driving field and the number of excited states that participate in the process.
In conclusion, we explore how our findings may shed light on recent experimental observations related to the creation of nonclassical light through spontaneous emission processes.

We introduce fresh Chandra observations of the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) in Abell 3395 (z=0.084).
The BCG was enveloped by a broad halo, featuring temperatures that ranged from 1 keV to 5 keV.
Our observations indicate that this hot gas has been moved from its initial position surrounding the central galaxy as a result of interactions with other galaxies in the cluster's core.
Through our analysis, we have identified two radio sources linked to the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG), which are probably associated with AGN jets or lobes.
In conclusion, we pinpoint various areas where cold gas could have formed from the surrounding hot plasma.
These findings indicate that the BCG in Abell 3395 is experiencing considerable interaction with its surrounding environment.

We investigate the electrical excitation of nonlinear waves within a two-dimensional channel, where a voltage bias is applied across two parallel metal plates separated by a dielectric layer.
We demonstrate that various types of nonlinear waves can be generated based on the system's parameters, such as the thickness of the dielectric layer and the electron density.
Specifically, we observe that solitary wave solutions exist for certain values of these parameters, resembling those previously discovered in one-dimensional systems.

The presence of these solitary waves has been experimentally validated through time-resolved optical reflectivity measurements conducted at room temperature on samples made of GaAs/AlGaAs quantum wells, which were produced using molecular beam epitaxy.
These experiments demonstrate the existence of bright solitary waves traveling in a direction perpendicular to the applied electric field.
Their propagation velocities align closely with the theoretical predictions derived from numerical simulations of the underlying equations.

The results discussed here could have significant implications for semiconductor devices, as recent studies have demonstrated that the generation of solitary waves enhances performance characteristics.
We report new spectroscopic observations of two globular clusters located in the nearby galaxy NGC 5128, commonly referred to as Centaurus A.
The globular clusters are situated at estimated distances ranging from approximately 3 kpc to 10 kpc from the center of this elliptical galaxy.
We acquired high-resolution spectra using Gemini/GMOS-S across three separate nights in 2013 and 2014.
These data enable us to accurately measure radial velocities for both globular clusters to within 1 km/sec or better.
Furthermore, we also derive line-of-sight velocity dispersions from the same GMOS-S data.
In the case of one particular cluster, we observe that its systemic velocity aligns closely with earlier measurements reported by other researchers.
Nonetheless, our measurement for the second cluster diverges considerably from the values published earlier.
This discrepancy could arise from contamination by an underlying stellar population or possibly from a misclassification as a globular cluster (GC).

We report the findings from our analysis of globular cluster (GC) systems in four massive elliptical galaxies: NGC 4889, NGC 4636, NGC 5846, and NGC 6166. This study utilizes deep imaging data from the Hubble Space Telescope, captured with the Advanced Camera for Surveys Wide Field Channel.

Our analysis reveals that these globular cluster (GC) systems are multimodal, comprising at least two distinct subpopulations that vary considerably in both their color distributions and spatial arrangements within each galaxy.
The blue subpopulation is more densely concentrated at the center compared to the red subpopulation, although both groups exhibit similar radial profiles in their outer regions.
These results indicate that the formation histories of the two subpopulations could differ.

Specifically, we suggest that the blue subpopulation was created during significant mergers between gas-rich disk galaxies, while the red subpopulation was built up through minor mergers and/or the accretion of dwarf galaxies or low-mass ellipticals.

The Coulomb drag effect occurs when one charge carrier transfers energy to another through the exchange of virtual phonons, resulting in an electric current in the second carrier that opposes its direction of movement.
In this study, we investigate the Coulomb drag effect between two graphene sheets that are separated by a dielectric spacer layer and influenced by varying gate voltages.

Our observations indicate that at small separation distances (less than 10 nm), there are notable discrepancies from the predictions derived from the conventional theory established for bulk materials.
These discrepancies occur because of the existence of evanescent modes that strongly interact with carriers at low energy levels.
As anticipated, these effects become insignificant for larger separations.
The findings shared in this report offer valuable insights for designing devices like transistors and thermoelectric generators that utilize graphene layers.

I. INTRODUCTION  
Graphene has garnered significant interest in recent times due to its distinctive electronic properties [1].
It is made up of carbon atoms organized in a honeycomb lattice structure and exhibits properties similar to a two-dimensional electron gas when doped [2].
One fascinating characteristic of graphene is the phenomenon known as the Coulomb drag effect.

This refers to the production of an electric current in a second layer of electrons as they move through a first layer of electrons, despite the fact that they do not directly interact with each other.
This phenomenon occurs as a result of the exchange of virtual phonons between the two carriers, facilitated by their interaction through the substrate [5].
As a result, the current density in the second carrier is influenced by the velocity of the first carrier [6].

Transient enhanced diffusion (TED), which refers to the redistribution of dopants following high-energy implantation and subsequent rapid thermal annealing (RTA), has been the subject of extensive research over the last twenty years [1].

The prevailing models for simulating TED generally assume that all excess interstitials generated during implantation remain immobile at room temperature.

In this study, we introduce an effective watermarking method for digital images that utilizes the discrete wavelet transform (DWT).

**1 Introduction**  
Planets originate from dust particles that coalesce through various coagulation mechanisms (Safronov 1969; Wetherill & Stewart 1989), subsequently leading to runaway accretion onto these developing bodies (Lissauer 1987).
This process results in the creation of planetesimals, with masses varying from 10$^{−6}$ times the mass of Earth to several times that of Earth.

With sufficient material accumulation in a short period, these bodies can develop into larger planetary embryos or even transform directly into gas giants similar to Jupiter and Saturn (Pollack et al. 1996).
After they are formed, these gigantic planets create gaps in the nearby circumstellar disks as a result of the tidal torques produced by their gravitational pull (Lin & Papaloizou 1986).
As a result, the residual material within this gap will be quickly removed due to viscosity effects, causing the planet to migrate inward swiftly in a type II manner (Ward 1997; Tanaka et al. 2002).

The distribution of observed exoplanets reveals a diverse range of orbital configurations, including circular orbits around Sun-like stars and highly eccentric orbits around low-mass stars (see, for example, Marcy et al. (2005), Udry & Santos (2007), Winn et al. (2010), Johnson et al. (2011), and the references cited therein).
Nonetheless, many of them have been discovered in close proximity to their host star, where the likelihood of detection rises significantly due to the intense stellar activity.

We introduce an effective numerical approach for addressing the nonlinear dynamics of semiconductor microcavity lasers, accommodating various pumping profiles and cavity losses. This method utilizes a combination of two distinct truncation techniques.

The initial method was designed to streamline the number of equations by removing all but those that are pertinent at a specific moment; this enables us to achieve precise results even when only a limited number of modes play a significant role in the overall emission spectrum.
The second method was used to remove the rapidly oscillating terms that arise from the presence of multiple longitudinal modes within each family of transverse modes.
We demonstrate how these two techniques can be integrated into a unified algorithm that we refer to as "dynamics-controlled truncation" (DCT).
In conclusion, we illustrate the precision and effectiveness of our approach by comparing it with other established methods.
Specifically, we examine three distinct types of pumping profiles: constant, periodic, and random pulsed pumping.

The Internet Archive (IA) is a digital library that offers open access to a collection dedicated to preserving and providing access to the cultural heritage of the web.
Since 1996, the Internet Archive has been gathering data through the Wayback Machine service, which regularly crawls the web to capture and archive snapshots of websites.
In this study, we introduce an innovative method for efficiently storing large quantities of archived web pages by taking advantage of their built-in redundancy.

We introduce a novel storage model named WARCStore, which is founded on the principle of inverted files. In this model, each page is represented as a collection of records that include its content along with links to other related pages stored within the same file system.
This enables us to keep several copies of the same page in various locations, all while ensuring quick random read/write capabilities.
Our experiments demonstrate that our proposed solution surpasses current alternatives, such as B-tree indexes and LSM-trees, in efficiently storing millions of archived web pages.

We investigate the gravitational waves generated by the curvaton scenario, in which the inflaton field is linked to an additional scalar field known as the curvaton. This curvaton decays into radiation after inflation, leading to the production of primordial density fluctuations.

We discover that the amplitude of gravitational waves produced during inflation can increase if the curvaton's decay rate is sufficiently large in relation to the Hubble parameter at the time of its decay.

In this scenario, we demonstrate that the tensor-to-scalar ratio exceeds 0.1 for the majority of parameter values, unless the curvaton's mass is very small or the interaction between the inflaton and curvaton fields is significantly weak.
This finding may help clarify why recent observations indicate a significantly high tensor-to-scalar ratio.

We present findings on the valley-dependent optoelectronic properties of monolayer WSe2, a semiconductor characterized by its lack of inversion symmetry, significant spin-orbit coupling, and high exciton binding energy.
We demonstrate that circularly polarized light can effectively manipulate the valley polarization of photoexcited carriers through optical pumping at room temperature.
The lifetime of valley polarization was measured to be approximately 1 ns for both electrons and holes when subjected to weak excitation conditions.
This research paves the way for new possibilities in the development of innovative valleytronic devices utilizing 2D materials.
Valleytronics has emerged as a promising method for achieving spin-based electronics that go beyond traditional silicon technology.
Recent studies have demonstrated that the valley degree of freedom can significantly influence various physical phenomena, including phonon transport, thermoelectricity, and superconductivity.
Monolayer transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) are novel two-dimensional semiconductors characterized by broken inversion symmetry, a feature arising from their distinctive layered structure.
They have garnered significant interest due to their exceptional electronic, mechanical, thermal, and optical properties.
Furthermore, transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) exhibit excellent carrier mobility, which positions them as promising candidates for future valleytronic applications.
In this study, we showcase the valley-dependent optoelectronic characteristics of monolayer WSe2 through the use of time-resolved photoluminescence spectroscopy.
When WSe2 is excited using circularly polarized light, we find that the valley polarization lifetimes of the photo-excited carriers, both electrons and holes, are approximately 1 ns.
Our findings offer clear evidence of valley-dependent optoelectronic processes within this material system.

We present a model that explains the spontaneous emergence of neuronal assemblies through an unsupervised Hebbian learning mechanism characterized by synaptic depression.
The network consisted of N neurons interconnected through excitatory connections, with the strength of these connections varying based on their firing rates, following a depressing function.
We demonstrate how this mechanism results in the formation of stable states that exhibit varying levels of average activity and different quantities of synchronized clusters.

We specifically discover that there is a critical threshold for the connection probability, beyond which the system experiences a phase transition into a state where all neurons fire synchronously at high rates.
This condition aligns with what has been observed in experiments as ictal seizures.
Additionally, we investigate how external stimulation influences the dynamics of our network.
By delivering short electrical pulses to targeted groups of neurons, we can provoke shifts between various dynamic states.
Lastly, we explore the potential applications of these findings in the field of neurobiology.
This thesis focuses on the study and development of computational methods for prolongation structures, which serve as valuable tools in the field of geometric analysis.
The primary emphasis is on developing explicit formulas for the extended action of vector fields on tensor bundles over manifolds that exhibit symmetries.

We apply our findings to calculate the prolonged actions of several significant examples, such as the Killing vector fields on homogeneous spaces and the conformal vector fields on conformally flat manifolds.
In conclusion, we demonstrate how our findings can be utilized to create new families of solutions to Einstein's equations.

We provide an analysis of N-body simulations designed to explore the impact of evaporation on the mass function (MF) of globular clusters (GCs).

Our findings are consistent with earlier research, indicating that evaporation leads globular clusters (GCs) to preferentially lose low-mass stars, which in turn results in a steeper mass function slope at lower masses.

Nonetheless, we demonstrate that this effect is offset by two opposing mechanisms: dynamical friction, which removes massive stars more effectively than their less massive counterparts, and relaxation-driven core collapse, which raises the central density of the cluster, thereby making it more difficult for massive stars to escape.
The overall outcome is highly influenced by the initial concentration of the cluster, often resulting in shallower slopes than those seen in actual globular clusters (GCs).
This indicates that additional processes were necessary to account for the observed shape of the mass function.
Specifically, our findings indicate that primordial binaries could play a key role in generating the high-mass power-law tail observed in numerous globular clusters.
We provide optical and near-infrared photometric data for SN 2006bp, which was identified on September 24th in NGC 6946 by amateur astronomer Brian Puckett (Puckett et al., 2007).
The supernova was situated at an unusually great distance from its host galaxy, exhibiting a recession velocity of approximately 1000 km/sec.
Our analysis reveals that the light curve is effectively modeled by three key components: shock breakout emission, luminosity powered by radioactive decay, and dust extinction.
With this model, we obtain key physical parameters including the progenitor's radius, the rate of mass loss, and the energy of the explosion.
Our findings align with those observed in other type-II supernovae, but indicate that the progenitor star likely had a lower initial mass than previously estimated.
This might suggest that there is greater diversity among the progenitors of type-II supernovae than previously acknowledged.
Beyond these findings, our observations offer fresh perspectives on the physics of shock breakout and the early evolution of type-II supernovae.

The Littlewood-Richardson polynomials are a crucial instrument in representation theory, and they also have numerous applications in various other fields.
Richard Stanley introduced them in 1973, as detailed in his book "Enumerative Combinatorics."
The original definition is complex; here we present an equivalent one that presents them in a manner more akin to conventional symmetric functions.
We subsequently define the Schur polynomials by employing these polynomials in place of the standard monomial basis.
In conclusion, we demonstrate that this new definition is consistent with the previous one in the context of the ring of symmetric functions.

This article is intended for readers who are already familiar with the fundamental concepts of symmetric functions and are interested in exploring their applications in the study of group representations.
It presupposes an understanding of group actions on vector spaces, the characters of finite groups, and the tensor products of vector spaces.
For additional background information, refer to the sections on Group (mathematics) or Representation Theory.

We investigated the rheological properties of isotropic networks created by crosslinking actin filaments with two varying concentrations of biotin-avidin linkers. This was achieved through microrheology experiments focusing on single filament dynamics, alongside macrorheology measurements conducted at low frequencies ranging from 0.01 to 10 Hz.
Our findings indicate that both micro- and macro-rheology align with an elastic network model, allowing us to derive values for the link density between filaments and their stiffness.
The findings indicate that a higher concentration of avidin results in more compact networks with stronger connections.
This effect becomes more significant when the initial concentration of actin filaments is increased.
Our research indicates that the mechanical properties of actomyosin gels can be adjusted by varying the quantity and/or type of crosslinking agents used in these systems.
Inside living cells, cytoskeletal structures like stress fibers and focal adhesions establish physical links between cellular components, significantly influencing the mechanics of the cell. [1]
These structures are made up of groups of semiflexible biopolymers called actin filaments, which are linked together by distinct protein complexes known as crosslinks.
In recent years, there has been an increasing interest in exploring how the mechanical properties of biological materials are influenced by the microscopic structure of their underlying networks [4].
Recent studies have demonstrated that the viscoelastic properties of reconstituted actomyosin gels are significantly influenced by the presence of myosin proteins [5].
Despite this progress, our understanding of how the macroscopic behavior of complex fluids relates to the microstructure of their constituent building blocks is still limited [6].
We provide an exact solution to the classical equations of motion in two dimensions, interpreted as representing a rotating black hole with angular momentum J equal to M.
The metric is expressed as \( ds^2 = -dt^2 + (1 + \cosh^2 r) d\theta^2 - r^2 dr^2 \), with \( r \) and \( \theta \) representing the polar coordinates in the plane.
This solution can be derived by applying a duality transformation to the standard BTZ black hole that is non-rotating.
We demonstrate that this new solution meets all the necessary physical conditions at infinity.
Specifically, we observe that it characterizes a regular black hole horizon positioned at \( r_+ = \sqrt{3}M \), with \( M \) representing the mass parameter in the original BTZ solution.
In conclusion, we explore several potential generalizations of our findings.
Introduction: In recent years, numerous efforts have been made to develop solutions to Einstein's field equations that pertain to rotating black holes [1] - [4].

A particularly fascinating category of solutions was discovered by Bañados, Teitelboim, and Zanelli (BTZ), who demonstrated how to derive a static black hole solution within three-dimensional anti-de Sitter space-time [5].

The key characteristic of these solutions is their asymptotic behavior, as they represent black holes for which the event horizons are entirely defined by global parameters such as total energy or charge [6].

Nonetheless, while these solutions serve as valuable tools for exploring quantum gravity phenomena [7, 8], they do not offer insights into the local characteristics of spacetime in the vicinity of the horizon [9].

Consequently, it appears beneficial to explore the possibility of extending these concepts into more complex geometries that include additional parameters defining the black hole's internal structure [10].
One approach to achieve this is by exploring higher-dimensional extensions of the BTZ solution [11].
Another option is to carry out a duality transformation on established solutions [12].

For instance, beginning with the Schwarzschild solution presented in spherical coordinates, we can apply an appropriate coordinate transformation to obtain an alternative solution expressed in oblate spheroidal coordinates [13].

We evaluate the performance of two methods for simulating non-equilibrium dynamics in polymer systems: dissipative particle dynamics (DPD) using either a Nosé-Hoover thermostat or a Langevin thermostat.
We demonstrate that both DPD schemes yield qualitatively comparable results when contrasted with each other and with experimental data on the stretching of individual DNA molecules.
Nevertheless, we observe notable quantitative differences between the two approaches, arising from the fact that they employ fundamentally different equations of motion.
Specifically, we illustrate how these variations influence the relaxation behavior following the application of an external force at the ends of the chain.
In conclusion, we explore potential approaches to address the limitations present in the current implementations.

This simplification allows for efficient sampling of the configurational space through the use of Monte Carlo methods or Molecular Dynamics.

The color reconnection (CR) model explains the process by which quarks and gluons rearrange into hadrons following their production in hard scattering events, like those that take place during e+e- annihilation.
The CR model suggests that particles emitted in close proximity within phase space are more likely to recombine compared to those that are farther apart.
This effect could result in alterations to the event topology and kinematics when compared to predictions derived from models that do not incorporate cosmic rays.
In this analysis, we utilize data gathered from the Delphi experiment, which was conducted at center-of-mass energies ranging from 189 GeV to 209 GeV, with a total integrated luminosity of 1.1 fb⁻¹.

We calculate the proportion of WW events in which one or both W bosons decay leptonically across various ranges of dilepton invariant mass. We then compare these findings to Monte Carlo simulations, both with and without considering CR effects.
Our measurements reveal no substantial evidence of CR effects when considering our experimental uncertainties.
The creation of dipoles in self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) on metal surfaces is studied using scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy (STM/STS).

The self-assembled monolayer (SAM) is composed of octadecanethiols featuring an end group with one or two thiocyanate groups, which are recognized for generating strong dipole moments when adsorbed onto gold substrates.
The presence of these highly polarizable groups results in substantial alterations to the electronic structure of the self-assembled monolayer (SAM) when compared to nonpolar alkane chains.
Specifically, we note a movement of the molecular states to higher energy levels, along with a decrease in their spatial extent perpendicular to the surface.
These effects can be understood through a straightforward model that focuses on the electrostatic interactions between the molecules and the substrate.
Our findings illustrate the way chemical functionalization enables the customization of the properties of organic films applied to metallic surfaces.
The formation of dipoles at the interfaces of alkanethiolate self-assembled monolayers and Ag(111) has been investigated through scanning tunneling microscopy/spectroscopy (STM/S).

The self-assembled monolayer (SAM) is formed through the chemisorption of octadecanethiol featuring thiocyanate end groups on Ag(111), producing a film characterized by a significant dipole moment per unit area.
STM images reveal well-organized structures made up of bright protrusions arranged in rows, which are interspersed with darker regions.
STS measurements indicate that the molecular states shift toward higher energy values as one moves from the center of the row to its edge.
This phenomenon was ascribed to the electric field produced by the dipole layer.
We examined the kinematics of nearby solar-type stars (F and G dwarfs) ranging from 1 million to 10 billion years in age, utilizing data from Hipparcos astrometry.
We observe that there is no noteworthy variation in their velocity dispersion profiles across different ages.
The flat profile indicates that these stars are likely in nearly circular orbits around the Sun.
This finding reinforces our earlier conclusions derived from the analysis of open clusters.

The Marcus-Lushnikov process serves as the continuous-time counterpart to the discrete-time Lévy walk model, which was introduced by Montroll and Weiss in 1965 to illustrate diffusion-limited aggregation (DLA) occurring on fractal surfaces.

The DLA growth mechanism has been studied experimentally for many years; however, it is only in recent times that efforts have been made to mathematically model it using stochastic processes like the Marcus-Lushnikov process.
This article explores two interconnected issues related to the Marcus-Lushnikov model:

First, we demonstrate that if the jump distribution of the underlying Lévy process meets specific integrability conditions, then the associated Marcus-Lushnikov process converges weakly to a Brownian motion with drift. Second, we explain how the Marcus-Lushnikov model has been employed to approximate the solution to Smoluchowski's coagulation-fragmentation equation, which characterizes the evolution of particle size distributions in chemical reactions that involve clusters of particles.
We also explore certain links between the Marcus-Lushnikov model and Flory's polymerization model.
This study aims to examine the real estate market in Las Vegas (LV) through the use of Composite Shiller Weiss Indexes (CSWI).
The analysis is based on monthly sales prices of residential properties that were sold from January 2005 to December 2014.

To perform the addition, we utilize the autoregressive integrated moving average model with exogenous variables (ARIMAX). This model enables us to forecast future values of the indexes by leveraging historical data.
We observed an increase in property sales values during the analyzed period; however, these levels did not rise to the status of a bubble.
Nonetheless, the findings indicate that the Las Vegas real estate market has gone through phases of overvaluation since 2007.
In conclusion, our results indicate that the ARIMAX model can be effective for predicting the trends in the CSWI indexes.
Keywords: Real Estate Market; Forecasting Models; Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA)

We suggest utilizing photonic molecules—formed by coupling two or more microcavities with varied resonant wavelengths—as foundational elements for innovative lasers and optoelectronic devices.

We demonstrate that the coupling of these cavities can give rise to several intriguing phenomena, including: (i) the emergence of hybridized modes, (ii) the presence of sharp peaks in the emission spectrum at frequencies aligned with the avoided crossings of cavity eigenmodes, (iii) an increase in the spontaneous emission rate attributed to the Purcell effect, and (iv) significant alterations in optical gain characteristics driven by mode competition effects.

We present an impedance spectroscopic analysis of epitaxially grown thin films of BiFeO3 (BFO) and BaTiO3 (BT) with varying thicknesses, which were deposited onto single crystal SrTiO3 substrates using the pulsed laser deposition method.
The dielectric properties were examined over a temperature range of 300 K to 450 K, while varying the frequency between 1 kHz and 10 MHz.
Both BFO and BT exhibit ferroelectric properties, as demonstrated by their hysteresis loops, which are dependent on frequency.
Furthermore, we notice an anomaly around 420 K in all samples, which can be linked to the phase transition from a rhombohedral to a tetragonal structure in the BFO film.
We also observe that the dielectric constant decreases as the measurement frequency rises, while it increases when the sample thickness is reduced.
This observation implies that there is space charge polarization present in these films.
Additionally, the dielectric loss displays a significant dependence on both the measurement frequency and the thickness of the sample.

We assess the baryonic acoustic oscillation (BAO) scale in galaxy distribution by cross-correlating the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 5 with the Two Degree Field Galaxy Redshift Survey Data Release 3, focusing on the redshift range of z=0.35-0.55.
We employ two distinct estimators to determine the BAO peak position: one utilizes the correlation function, while the other relies on the power spectrum.

We examine a model of an enzymatic reaction network that features several futile cycles, positing that each enzyme is maintained at a constant concentration and that all reactions are reversible.
We demonstrate that there is a unique positive equilibrium point when the total quantity of enzymes is sufficiently greater than the total number of substrate molecules.
This finding can also be utilized in other models, including those that represent metabolic networks or gene regulatory systems.
The proof is based on the observation that the system exhibits a unique globally asymptotically stable equilibrium point when analyzed using mass action kinetics.
Furthermore, we demonstrate that this equilibrium point is locally exponentially stable, despite the fact that the system does not meet the traditional Lipschitz condition.
Ultimately, numerical simulations demonstrate our findings.
Keywords: Enzymatic reaction networks, mass action kinetics, steady-state analysis, metabolic pathways, gene regulation systems.

We introduce an evolutionary model that explains the development of genes, species, and their interactions through the lens of physical principles.
The model is grounded in the idea of self-assembly, which is a process that takes place during the formation of biological macromolecules like proteins and nucleic acids.
We demonstrate how this process results in the natural emergence of functional units that we refer to as "gene families."
Gene families are characterized by shared sequence motifs and can be regarded as foundational elements for more complex organisms.
In our method, these foundational elements develop into new species as a result of mutations and selection processes.
Species interact with one another through chemical reactions that are facilitated by enzymes.
These interactions give rise to metabolic networks, the structure of which mirrors the underlying network topology of the species involved.

In conclusion, we illustrate how the proposed model successfully replicates key characteristics seen in real-world systems, such as preferential attachment, scale-free degree distributions, and small-world properties.
Our findings indicate that the fundamental mechanisms underlying the evolution of life may have been established right from the outset.

We introduce an algorithm that evaluates the existence of a quantum circuit with a specific number of qubits and gates, ensuring that the associated time-independent Hamiltonian can be implemented in a physical system where each energy level accommodates no more than one excited state.
We also demonstrate the process for identifying all potential circuits, should they exist.
Our findings are grounded in recent research demonstrating that any time-independent Hamiltonian can be expressed as a sum of commuting projectors onto its eigenstates.

This decomposition enables us to transform the challenge of finding a realization of a general time-independent Hamiltonian into multiple instances of the same problem, each confined to smaller Hilbert spaces.
This reduction produces a polynomial-time algorithm when implemented recursively.
In conclusion, we explore several applications of our method, including the assessment of the minimum depth necessary for universal adiabatic quantum computers.

The vapor pressure, water solubility, and interfacial tension between oil and water are key factors for comprehending how crude oils behave during extraction and transportation through pipelines.
In this study, we examined these properties by utilizing alkanol monolayers on an aqueous subphase as model systems to replicate the hydrocarbon chains found in crude oils.
The findings indicate that the vapor pressures of the alkanols rise with chain length up to C8, but decline once the chain length surpasses C10.
This was elucidated by examining the competition between two contrasting effects: on one side, longer chain lengths result in larger molecular volumes, which promote evaporation.
Conversely, longer chains contribute to stronger van der Waals interactions in the liquid phase, which in turn leads to reduced vapor pressures.
We observe that the solubility patterns of the alkanols are consistent with the trends seen in their vapor pressures.
Nonetheless, the disparities in solubility between various chain lengths diminish when juxtaposed with the corresponding variations in vapor pressure.
Ultimately, our measurements indicate that the interfacial tensions between the alkanol layers and the water below consistently decrease as the chain length increases.

We conduct numerical simulations to investigate the formation, evolution, and collapse of quiescent cloud cores triggered by dynamic compressions within turbulent molecular clouds.
Our findings indicate that these cloud cores are created by shock compression occurring at the points where shocks, generated by supersonic turbulence, collide with the clouds.
The masses of cloud cores vary from 0.1 M⊙ to 1 M⊙, typically measuring around 1000 AU in size.

These cloud cores exhibit low internal velocities of less than 2 km s^-1, but throughout their lifetimes, they can be accelerated to speeds of up to 10 km s^-1 as a result of gravitational interactions with other dense clumps within the same clouds.
The majority of them undergo a quasi-static evolution for several free-fall times before collapsing dynamically over time scales that vary from one to ten free-fall times.
Our findings indicate that these cloud cores could be a significant source of prestellar objects in areas where stars are forming.

We present the detection of fluctuations in the cosmic far-infrared background (CFIRB) through deep observations conducted with the Far Infrared Surveyor (FIS) on the Akari satellite. These observations were made at the 65 and 90 micron bands in the Lockman Hole field, renowned for being one of the most sensitive areas for identifying extragalactic sources.
The FIS features two photometric channels: the N60 band spans from 60 to 120 microns, while the WIDE-S channel ranges from 50 to 100 microns.
We utilized data collected from February 2005 to March 2007.

After eliminating the bright point-like sources identified by the Spitzer/MIPS 24 micron survey, we conducted aperture photometry on all the remaining pixels within a 1 deg² area centered on the Lockman Hole.
To assess the contribution of Galactic cirrus emission, we applied a 3 sigma clipping method and then subtracted the median value from each pixel.
Subsequently, we computed the power spectrum density (PSD) for the residual map.
By applying a single power law model to the PSD, we determined the optimal slope to be -2.1 ± 0.3 at 65 microns and -1.9 ± 0.4 at 90 microns.
These slopes align with the anticipated clustering characteristics of infrared galaxies.

We investigate the Catalan numbers in relation to the various methods of representing a specific triangulation as an ordered sequence of its diagonals, which can also be understood as a collection of non-crossing diagonals.
We demonstrate that this issue is connected to the enumeration of specific kinds of Dyck paths.
Specifically, we demonstrate that for every positive integer n, there are precisely C(n) distinct sequences of diagonals that can be generated by a convex quadrilateral with 2n sides.
This outcome extends a theorem by Motzkin and Straus concerning the count of diagonalizations in a convex polygon.

This study focuses on a different category of Catalan-like structures: the triangulations of polygons (refer to Figure 1).

A triangulation T of a simple polygon P is defined as the collection of all the edges of P, along with additional diagonals that connect pairs of vertices within P, ensuring that each interior angle of P measures at least 90 degrees after the diagonals are added.
It follows directly from the fact that each edge is associated with exactly one diagonal of T.
In [3], the renowned theorem by Motzkin and Straus asserts that if D represents the set of diagonals of a convex polygon Q, then the relationship |D| = 2|Q| holds true.
They demonstrated that the number of diagonalizations d(P) of a convex polygon P is equal to the number of diagonals in a triangulation of P.
Recent findings have demonstrated that the number of diagonals in a triangulation of a convex quadrilateral is four times the number of diagonals required to diagonalize the quadrilateral.
This naturally leads to the question: What is the connection between the number of diagonals needed to diagonalize a convex quadrilateral and the number of diagonals utilized in a triangulation?

The origin and evolution of cosmic magnetic fields represent one of the most significant unresolved challenges in astrophysics. This issue is intricately linked to several other fundamental topics, including star formation, galaxy formation, and the development of cosmic structures.
In this presentation, I will discuss our recent research on simulating primordial magnetic fields, highlighting various physical processes that are involved.
The initial section concentrates on the creation of seed magnetic fields during inflation as a result of quantum fluctuations.
We demonstrate that these seeds can be greatly amplified after reheating as a result of the magnetohydrodynamic turbulence caused by the decaying inflaton perturbations.
Next, we explore how these seeds develop into extensive, coherent magnetic fields via several mechanisms, such as inverse cascade, dynamo action, and turbulent pumping.
In conclusion, we outline several potential observational signatures for future detection.
This presentation took place at the International Conference on Computation & Theory (ICCT), which was held in Beijing, China, from September 24 to 27, 2014.

We investigate the ground-state characteristics of two-flavor color superconducting (2SC) quark matter at finite density and temperature by employing an effective chiral model that incorporates vector interactions, which has been derived from QCD within the mean-field approximation.
We have discovered a novel type of 2SC phase in which quarks form diquark condensates that have distinct colors but share the same flavor.
This new phase is referred to as the Larkin-Ovchinnikova-Fulde-Ferrell (LOFF) state, as it was initially introduced to account for superfluidity in nuclear systems.
In this LOFF state, we demonstrate that the gap parameter for pairing quarks with opposite momenta is influenced by the angle between them.
The size of the gap decreases quickly as they move apart along the Fermi surface.
As a result, the energy gap completely disappears near the boundary of the Brillouin zone.
We investigate the effectiveness of cosmic ray (CR) acceleration by relativistic shocks through a combination of Monte Carlo simulations and analytical computations.
Our analysis indicates that in the case of strong shocks with a Mach number ranging from 10 to 100, only approximately 1% of cosmic rays can be accelerated to ultra-high energy (UHE).
This occurs because the majority of particles are reflected back upstream before they accumulate enough energy to re-cross the shock front.
The inefficiency in producing ultra-high-energy (UHE) particles imposes a ceiling on both the maximum proton energy and the total cosmic ray (CR) luminosity generated by these shocks.
Our findings indicate that the detected fluxes of UHE protons cannot be solely accounted for by the diffusive shock acceleration mechanism at work in cosmological shocks.
Nevertheless, our results do not eliminate the possibility of alternative mechanisms that have been recently suggested to account for the origin of UHE cosmic rays.
Cosmic ray acceleration, particularly through mechanisms like diffusive shock acceleration at relativistic shocks, plays a crucial role in understanding high-energy astrophysical phenomena.
